title: Brute Force Attack Analysis
description:
Scenario: Multiple failed login attempts against a single user account have been detected. Investigate potential brute force attacks targeting high-value accounts.

Learning Objectives: Basic filtering, counting operations, and user-focused analysis.

Data Sources: SigninLogs table from Microsoft Entra ID

expectedResults.successCriteria: Identifies users with excessive failed login attempts

progressiveHints.title: ðŸŽ¯ Focus on Failures
progressiveHints.content: Start by filtering for failed login attempts using ResultType != 0, then focus on analyzing patterns of failed attempts against user accounts.

progressiveHints.title: ðŸ‘¤ Target Specific Users
progressiveHints.content: Look for patterns where a single user has many failed attempts. Use 'summarize' to count failures per user account - this is different from password spray which groups by IP.

progressiveHints.title: ðŸ“Š Add Source Analysis
progressiveHints.content: Brute force attacks may come from multiple IPs. Add source IP information and time ranges to your analysis to understand the attack pattern.
progressiveHints.example: | summarize FailedAttempts = count(), SourceIPs = make_set(IPAddress), FirstAttempt = min(TimeGenerated) by UserPrincipalName

progressiveHints.title: âš¡ Set Brute Force Threshold
progressiveHints.content: Typically 10+ failed attempts against a single user indicate brute force activity. Filter for users with high failure counts to focus on real attacks.

progressiveHints.title: ðŸŽ¯ Sort and Prioritize
progressiveHints.content: Order results by failure count to see the most attacked accounts first. This helps security teams prioritize their incident response efforts.

walkthrough.title: ðŸ§  Brute Force Attack: KQL Detective Work
walkthrough.subtitle: Understanding how brute force differs from password spray attacks and why user-focused analysis matters

challenge.title: ðŸŽ¯ The Challenge: What Makes Brute Force Attacks Different?
challenge.description: Brute force attacks have a distinct signature:
points: **High intensity per user** - Many attempts against specific accounts
**Targeted approach** - Focuses on valuable accounts (admin, service accounts)
**Rapid execution** - Fast succession of password attempts
**May use multiple IPs** - Distributed infrastructure to avoid detection
challenge.detectiveWork: Find patterns that show _many attempts â†’ single target â†’ persistent behavior_

solution.title: ðŸ“ Our Detective Query
solution.query:
SigninLogs
| where TimeGenerated > ago(24h)        // ðŸ• Recent activity only
| where ResultType != 0                 // âŒ Failed logins only
| summarize                            // ðŸ“Š Group and analyze
    FailedAttempts = count(),               // ðŸ”¢ Total attempts per user
    SourceIPs = make_set(IPAddress),        // ðŸŒ All attacking IPs
    UniqueIPs = dcount(IPAddress),          // ðŸ“Š Count of unique sources
    FirstAttempt = min(TimeGenerated),      // â° Attack start
    LastAttempt = max(TimeGenerated)        // â° Attack end
    by UserPrincipalName                    // ðŸ‘¤ Group by USER (not IP!)
| where FailedAttempts >= 10           // âš ï¸ Brute force threshold
| extend AttackDuration = LastAttempt - FirstAttempt,    // â±ï¸ Time span
         AttemptsPerHour = FailedAttempts / (datetime_diff('hour', LastAttempt, FirstAttempt) + 1)  // ðŸ“ˆ Attack rate
| order by FailedAttempts desc         // ðŸ“Š Most attacked users first

reasoningSteps.title: Start with Failed Authentications
reasoningSteps.explanation: Like password spray, we focus on failed attempts. But our grouping strategy will be completely different.
reasoningSteps.detectiveInsight: Same starting point, different destination - we're looking for volume against specific targets.

reasoningSteps.title: Group by USER (Not IP!)
reasoningSteps.explanation: This is the key difference! We group by user account to find who is being attacked, not who is attacking.
reasoningSteps.detectiveInsight: Password spray: '1 IP â†’ many users'. Brute force: 'many attempts â†’ 1 user'. Flip the perspective!

reasoningSteps.title: Count Attack Intensity
reasoningSteps.explanation: High failure counts per user indicate automated password guessing against that specific account.
reasoningSteps.detectiveInsight: One user with 100 failed logins = under attack. 100 users with 1 failed login each = normal noise.

reasoningSteps.title: Track Attack Sources
reasoningSteps.explanation: Brute force attacks may come from multiple IPs. Collecting all source IPs shows the attack infrastructure.
reasoningSteps.detectiveInsight: Modern brute force uses botnets - many IPs attacking the same user reveals distributed attack patterns.

reasoningSteps.title: Set Volume Threshold
reasoningSteps.explanation: 10+ failures against one user is unusual and indicates automated attack behavior.
reasoningSteps.detectiveInsight: Legitimate users rarely fail 10+ times - this threshold separates attacks from normal user confusion.

resultInterpretation.title: ðŸŽ“ What Our Results Tell Us
resultInterpretation.description: When our query finds results, here's what each field reveals:

fields.meaning: This user account is under active brute force attack
Attack intensity - higher numbers indicate more persistent attacks
Attack infrastructure - multiple IPs suggest botnet or proxy usage
Attack distribution - single IP vs. many IPs reveals attack sophistication
How long the attack lasted - quick bursts vs. sustained campaigns
Attack rate - reveals automation level and detection avoidance tactics
